comment:
This was the first time I had played the
Slav Gambit. I think that I was first made aware of the ideas behind the
opening 3 0r 4 years ago when Edinburgh West were preparing for a Richardson
Cup match, but I had never tried it OTB. My book knowledge was limited to the
final chapter of Peter Wells' 1994 book on the Complete Semi-Slav, which
featured the game Lautier-Gurevich, Biel IZ 1993.

moves: 1. d4 e6 2. c4 d5 3. Nc3 c6 4. e4 dxe4 5. Nxe4 Bb4+ 6. Bd2 Qxd4 7. Bxb4 Qxe4+ 8. Be2 Na6 9. Bc3 Ne7 10. Bxg7 Rg8 11. Bf6 Qf4 12. Bc3 Rxg2 13. Nf3 f6
comment:
Analysis by Lautier and Wells suggests that 13...Rg8 should
be looked at as an alternative to 13...f6.

moves: 1. d4 e6 2. c4 d5 3. Nc3 c6 4. e4 dxe4 5. Nxe4 Bb4+ 6. Bd2 Qxd4 7. Bxb4 Qxe4+ 8. Be2 Na6 9. Bc3 Ne7 10. Bxg7 Rg8 11. Bf6 Qf4 12. Bc3 Rxg2 13. Nf3 f6 14. Qd2 Qxd2+ 15. Nxd2 e5 16. Ne4 Kf7 17. Rd1 Rg8
comment: Lautier and Wells analyse 17...Nc7 as better than 17...Rg8.

moves: 1. d4 e6 2. c4 d5 3. Nc3 c6 4. e4 dxe4 5. Nxe4 Bb4+ 6. Bd2 Qxd4 7. Bxb4 Qxe4+ 8. Be2 Na6 9. Bc3 Ne7 10. Bxg7 Rg8 11. Bf6 Qf4 12. Bc3 Rxg2 13. Nf3 f6 14. Qd2 Qxd2+ 15. Nxd2 e5 16. Ne4 Kf7 17. Rd1 Rg8 18. f4 Nf5
comment: # Departing from the Lautier-Gurevich game, which continued

moves: 1. d4 e6 2. c4 d5 3. Nc3 c6 4. e4 dxe4 5. Nxe4 Bb4+ 6. Bd2 Qxd4 7. Bxb4 Qxe4+ 8. Be2 Na6 9. Bc3 Ne7 10. Bxg7 Rg8 11. Bf6 Qf4 12. Bc3 Rxg2 13. Nf3 f6 14. Qd2 Qxd2+ 15. Nxd2 e5 16. Ne4 Kf7 17. Rd1 Rg8 18. f4 Nf5 19. fxe5 fxe5 20. Rf1 Ke7 21. Bxe5 Nb4
comment:
Black's plan of giving up the e5 pawn to mobilise the
Q-Knight is a reasonable try.

moves: 1. d4 e6 2. c4 d5 3. Nc3 c6 4. e4 dxe4 5. Nxe4 Bb4+ 6. Bd2 Qxd4 7. Bxb4 Qxe4+ 8. Be2 Na6 9. Bc3 Ne7 10. Bxg7 Rg8 11. Bf6 Qf4 12. Bc3 Rxg2 13. Nf3 f6 14. Qd2 Qxd2+ 15. Nxd2 e5 16. Ne4 Kf7 17. Rd1 Rg8 18. f4 Nf5 19. fxe5 fxe5 20. Rf1 Ke7 21. Bxe5 Nb4 22. Rd6 Nc2+ 23. Kd2 Rg2 24. Bf6+ Kf7 25. Bc3 Ne3 26. Rf6+ Kg8 27. Rf2 Rxf2 28. Nxf2 Bd7 29. Ne4 Rd8 30. Nd6 Bc8 31. c5 Nxd6 32. Kxe3 Re8+ 33. Kf3 Ne4 34. Bc4+ Be6 35. Rxe6 Ng5+ 36. Kg4 Nxe6 37. Kf5 Kf7 38. Bf6 b5 39. cxb6 axb6 40. a4 b5 41. axb5 cxb5 42. Bd5 b4 43. b3 Kf8 44. Bxe6
comment:
I was sure
at 2B+2P versus R+2P ending should be winning, but it isn't as easy as I first
thought. I felt there should be a way to get at the Black b-pawn, using the 2
Bishops to fend off the Rook.

moves: 1. d4 e6 2. c4 d5 3. Nc3 c6 4. e4 dxe4 5. Nxe4 Bb4+ 6. Bd2 Qxd4 7. Bxb4 Qxe4+ 8. Be2 Na6 9. Bc3 Ne7 10. Bxg7 Rg8 11. Bf6 Qf4 12. Bc3 Rxg2 13. Nf3 f6 14. Qd2 Qxd2+ 15. Nxd2 e5 16. Ne4 Kf7 17. Rd1 Rg8 18. f4 Nf5 19. fxe5 fxe5 20. Rf1 Ke7 21. Bxe5 Nb4 22. Rd6 Nc2+ 23. Kd2 Rg2 24. Bf6+ Kf7 25. Bc3 Ne3 26. Rf6+ Kg8 27. Rf2 Rxf2 28. Nxf2 Bd7 29. Ne4 Rd8 30. Nd6 Bc8 31. c5 Nxd6 32. Kxe3 Re8+ 33. Kf3 Ne4 34. Bc4+ Be6 35. Rxe6 Ng5+ 36. Kg4 Nxe6 37. Kf5 Kf7 38. Bf6 b5 39. cxb6 axb6 40. a4 b5 41. axb5 cxb5 42. Bd5 b4 43. b3 Kf8 44. Bxe6 Ra8 45. Bd4 Ra2 46. h3 Ke8 47. Kf6 Rc2 48. h4 Rc6
comment:
Manoeuvres to pick up the loose b-pawn are not so easy, as lines like
48.Bf5 Rd2 49.Bc5 Rd5 50.Bxb4 Rb5 demonstrate. I need to use the h-pawn as
well, to threaten mate if the Black King stays on the k-side, or to pick up
the h-pawn for the b-pawn and win the pawn race. The only thing to watch for
is by pushing the h-pawn to h6 to threaten mate, I could leave a stalemate if
Black sacs the Rook.

moves: 1. d4 e6 2. c4 d5 3. Nc3 c6 4. e4 dxe4 5. Nxe4 Bb4+ 6. Bd2 Qxd4 7. Bxb4 Qxe4+ 8. Be2 Na6 9. Bc3 Ne7 10. Bxg7 Rg8 11. Bf6 Qf4 12. Bc3 Rxg2 13. Nf3 f6 14. Qd2 Qxd2+ 15. Nxd2 e5 16. Ne4 Kf7 17. Rd1 Rg8 18. f4 Nf5 19. fxe5 fxe5 20. Rf1 Ke7 21. Bxe5 Nb4 22. Rd6 Nc2+ 23. Kd2 Rg2 24. Bf6+ Kf7 25. Bc3 Ne3 26. Rf6+ Kg8 27. Rf2 Rxf2 28. Nxf2 Bd7 29. Ne4 Rd8 30. Nd6 Bc8 31. c5 Nxd6 32. Kxe3 Re8+ 33. Kf3 Ne4 34. Bc4+ Be6 35. Rxe6 Ng5+ 36. Kg4 Nxe6 37. Kf5 Kf7 38. Bf6 b5 39. cxb6 axb6 40. a4 b5 41. axb5 cxb5 42. Bd5 b4 43. b3 Kf8 44. Bxe6 Ra8 45. Bd4 Ra2 46. h3 Ke8 47. Kf6 Rc2 48. h4 Rc6 49. h5 Kf8 50. Be3 Ke8 51. Ke5 Ke7 52. Bd5 Rc2 53. Bg5+ Ke8 54. Bc4 Rg2 55. Kf6 Kd7 56. Bd3 Rf2+ 57. Kg7 Rg2 58. Bxh7
comment:
The final tactic, which I spotted after 55...Kd7. The threat of Bf5+ stops
Black winning the b-pawn and returning to h3.
